context: Prologue — First day working at Torres Auto. Tutorial mechanics introduction.

lines.text: TORRES AUTO — DAY 1. Morning light cuts through the dusty garage windows.
Maya hands you a pair of faded coveralls with 'TORRES' stitched across the back. They smell like transmission fluid and old decisions.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Rule one: don't touch anything I don't tell you to touch. Rule two: if you break it, you buy it. Rule three: the radio stays on my station.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Any questions? Good. Let's start with the basics.
OIL CHANGE TUTORIAL
Maya rolls a Honda Civic onto the lift. It belongs to a regular — Mrs. Delgado, who apparently brings cookies every third visit.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Oil change. Bread and butter of every shop. Drain plug is underneath — fourteen millimeter. Don't strip it, or I'll make you tap a new one by hand.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Old oil out. New filter on. Five quarts of 5W-30. Check the dipstick twice. Simple — but do it wrong and you'll seize an engine.
You work through the oil change step by step. Maya watches, corrects your grip on the wrench, and nods when you check the dipstick.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Not bad. You didn't strip anything or spill too much. That puts you ahead of the last guy who worked here.
TIRE ROTATION
Next up: a tire rotation on a pickup truck that's seen better decades.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Tire rotation. Front to back, cross pattern. Torque spec is in the manual — don't guess. Under-torque and the wheel comes off at sixty. Over-torque and you'll crack the stud.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Check tread depth while you're at it. Penny test — if you can see Lincoln's whole head, they're done.
The work is monotonous but satisfying. There's a rhythm to it — loosen, lift, swap, torque. Your hands start to learn the language of the shop.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: You've got decent hands. Steady. That's more than most.
AFTERNOON — The shop quiets down. You're sweeping the bay when something catches your eye.
Behind a stack of parts catalogs on the workbench, a dog-eared magazine. UNDERGROUND SPEED — Nova Pacifica's Racing Scene. The cover shows a midnight street race, headlights blazing through fog.
You flip through it. Modified cars. Street circuits. Names like 'Diesel,' 'Jade,' 'The Ghost.' A whole world happening after dark, hidden in plain sight.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Hey. That's not — put that down.
She crosses the garage in three quick steps and takes the magazine from your hands. But she doesn't throw it away. She holds it for a moment, looking at the cover.

choices.text: You know about the racing scene?
That's the world I'm trying to get into.

lines.label: maya_racing_response
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Know about it? I...
She catches herself. Sets the magazine face-down on the workbench.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: That scene is trouble. Fast cars, fast money, faster ways to end up dead or broke. I've seen it chew people up.

lines.label: maya_racing_warning
lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: That world will eat you alive. You don't have the car, the money, or the connections. And it doesn't care about your dreams.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Focus on the work. Get your car running. Then... we'll see.

lines.label: first_day_end
lines.text: EVENING — The last customer picks up their car. Maya kills the bay lights.
Your arms ache. Your coveralls are streaked with grease. But for the first time in a long time, the ache feels earned.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Not bad for day one. Couch is in the back. There's leftover takeout in the fridge — help yourself.

lines.speaker: Maya Torres
lines.text: Get some sleep. Tomorrow we start on YOUR car. And trust me — it's going to need everything.
The couch is lumpy, the springs protest, and the office smells like brake cleaner. But as you stare at the ceiling, you can still hear it — that GT-R's engine, the green light, the spark.
Something woke up last night. And it's not going back to sleep.
